image.altText: Natasha Stott Despoja at a media conference.

props.synopsis: SA's Commissioner into Domestic, Family and Sexual Violence Natasha Stott Despoja is no stranger to taking on a big task. But the job of tackling domestic, family and sexual violence in the state requires structural, practical and cultural change. Despite countless harrowing tales, she remains hopeful that can be achieved, Jessica Haynes writes.

title.children: ‘Never been able to escape’: DV commissioner still hopeful despite harrowing stories

image.altText: A man in a high vis green top and a green hat in a carpark outside with a sunny blue sky.

props.synopsis: People living with disability in regional South Australia say it is hard to navigate new career paths as they do not have enough employment opportunities in their towns.

title.children: People living with disability seek more variety in job opportunities

image.altText: A car parked outside a home, with police tape in the foreground.

props.synopsis: A post-mortem report had listed the victim's cause of death as "unascertained", while the alleged killer was granted release on home detention bail, but was not released as a suitable address was not identified.

title.children: Alleged murder victim's body not found for 20 days, court hears

image.altText: Three people walking on a beach.

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says he does not want to "get into semantics" over categorising South Australia's devastating algal bloom as a national disaster but will "provide support as requested".

title.children: PM sticks to 'event', rather than 'disaster', to describe SA algal bloom

image.altText: Izak Rankine running with the ball, looking for a teammate to kick to in an AFL match.

props.synopsis: The AFL grants Adelaide's request for more time to respond to the league's "proposed determinations" over an alleged homophobic slur by Crows star Izak Rankine.

title.children: AFL gives Crows more time to respond as Rankine decision drags on

image.altText: A woman standing in front of a stone building.

props.synopsis: The Liberal Party names its candidates for the state's South East seats, currently held by independents facing unrelated legal troubles.

title.children: Two Liberal women hope to capture SA seats from controversial independents

image.altText: A person in shadow walks through a caged internal courtyard covered in more shadows.

props.synopsis: A new report has revealed isolations at South Australia's only youth detention centre increased by 50 per cent during a period last year and has questioned the legality of their use, with one respondent saying they felt they were being "punished like a dog".

title.children: 'Punished like a dog': Report reveals increase in isolations at SA youth detention centre

image.altText: Defeated SA Best leader Nick Xenophon with his successful candidates.

props.synopsis: Independent-turn-Liberal Frank Pangallo has styled himself as "the watchdog" in the lead-up to the 2026 state election, but time will tell if the gamble pays off, writes Daniel Keane.

title.children: Will a former journalist help the Liberals recapture this 'blue ribbon' seat?

image.altText: Ukraine's ambassador to Japan Sergiy Korsunsky walks past a map.

props.synopsis: A decade ago, Donetsk was the metropolis of Ukraine's east. Now, Russian President Vladimir Putin reportedly has it squarely in his sights.

title.children: The territories Putin wants and what it will mean for Ukraine

image.altText: A group of people sit around a long, oval table inside parliament house.

props.synopsis: The productivity roundtable's final day may prove the trickiest yet, as the conversation shifts from broad ambition to the hard realities of looming budget deficits and tax reform.

title.children: NDIS shake-up sets stage for summit showdown on budget cuts, tax reform

image.altText: Mark Butler speaking at the National press club

props.synopsis: Health and Disability Minister Mark Butler says he will not leave parents with children on the NDIS "high and dry" and has pledged to create a new system that will better support their needs. Follow live.

title.children: Butler says he will not leave parents with children on NDIS 'high and dry'

image.altText: Michele Vanderlanh Smith balcony

props.synopsis: As insurance premiums across the country rise, insurers are posting bumper profits. Consumer advocates say policyholders have a right to know why.

title.children: Consumers left in the dark about steep hikes to insurance premium

props.synopsis: Industry advocates say the federal government must do the heavy lifting when it comes to overhauling the child care sector.

title.children: Childcare safety is Australia's moment of reckoning, expert says

image.altText: An emperor penguin lies down in the snow, behind a small grey fluffy penguin chick.

props.synopsis: Scientists say there is emerging evidence of abrupt and potentially unstoppable changes in the Antarctic environment, heightening the risk of significant sea level rise and the extinction of species.

title.children: Scientists warn of 'abrupt changes' taking place in Antarctica

image.altText: Donald Trump with one arm raised in a fist above his head.

props.synopsis: Meta, Citigroup, and local school districts are among the companies and government entities which the US president has bought bonds from in the past seven months, disclosure logs show.

title.children: Donald Trump buys $155 million in bonds in months since inauguration

image.altText: Jeffrey Epstein appears in court.

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump had called for the release of the transcripts amid rumours and criticism about his involvement with late financier long ago.

title.children: Judge rejects Trump administration's bid to unseal Epstein transcripts

image.altText: Kassem in blazer and glasses, looking at paperwork

props.synopsis: Investors have been left wondering if they'll get their share of $33 million back from a health fund investor after it was purchased by another company.

title.children: 'My future is gone': Investors left in the dark after $33 million freeze

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Australian shares are likely to open higher, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 have fallen as investors have sold tech stocks and moved into less highly valued sectors. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX to rise while Wall Street sells tech

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Consumers in dark over insurance premium hikes

image.altText: Small white star speck surrounded by a transparent greyish cloud against a black background.

image.altText: A graphic shows three men in front of a green background.

image.altText: A woman at a table looking at her AI companion on her phone.

props.synopsis: Hayley's AI companion is credited with changing her life but for others they can be used for sex or even convey sinister overtones, Raising questions over whether the industry needs regulation.

title.children: 'Relationship she might not have had': Hayley's AI partner changed her life

image.altText: An older woman wearing a hat with a 'GrannySaurus' name plate and a boy wearing a novelty hat and sunglasses.

props.synopsis: A drunk driver who struck and killed 83-year-old Mary Kathleen Kelly on the Gold Coast is given a suspended jail term, as the victim's family continue to mourn the loss of her "contagious, exuberant energy".

title.children: Drink driver given suspended sentence over grandmother's hit-run death

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann holds an umbrella while walking.

props.synopsis: Wednesday's hearing didn't start smoothly for the former Liberal staffer with Federal Court judges questioning the logic of his grounds of appeal.

image.altText: Powelines surrounded by trees and shrubs fill a sunrise sky.

props.synopsis: There are concerns WA's transition to renewable energy could be even further delayed, with $3 billion in federal funds sitting idle more than two years after they were announced.

title.children: Billions set aside for WA's clean energy transition still unspent

image.altText: Joaquin Phoenix is on a phone call, dressed as a sheriff in the film Eddington.

props.synopsis: It might just about be the only thing the majority of the world agrees upon: Nobody wants to talk or even think about 2020. Enter Eddington: the wild, unpredictable fourth feature by Ari Aster, the American writer-director behind acclaimed horrors Hereditary and Midsommar.

title.children: Eddington is a deranged film about 2020

image.altText: A black and white photo of a horse behind a gate in a paddock with a shooting star in the top left hand corner of the shot.

image.altText: A man smiling in a suit, walking into a room full of people.

title.children: Who is Josh Willie, new leader of Tasmanian Labor?

image.altText: A white woman with brown hair touches the side of her face as she poses for a photo

props.synopsis: From having to give up a job, to feeling like life is on hold, readers share the challenges and guilt around caring for an aging parent.
